## Easy interactive widgets greatly expand student independance in data analysis 

.pull-left[

```{r plot-last, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}

# Import & Tidy data

atr <- read_csv("data/atr.csv") %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = 2:4, 
               names_to = "plastic",
               values_to = "intensity")

# Create plot

p <- ggplot(data = atr,
            aes(x = wavenumber, 
                y = intensity, 
                colour = plastic)) +
  geom_point()


# interactive plot

ggplotly(p)

```
]

.pull-right[
```{r echo = FALSE}

# Import & Tidy data

atr <- read_csv("data/atr.csv") %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = 2:4, 
               names_to = "plastic",
               values_to = "intensity")

# Create plot

p <- ggplot(data = atr,
            aes(x = wavenumber, 
                y = intensity, 
                colour = plastic)) +
  geom_point(size = 1)


# interactive plot

ggplotly(p)
```
]

???

- This snippet replaces a lot of commercial software...
